Furthermore Leeson’s reputation as an agency trader was helped greatly by BFS being the biggest trader on SIMEX, and that was attributable to the unauthorised trading.

D&T’s contentions on this point seem to me persuasive. Leeson’s unauthorised trading had the side-effect of increasing his reputation as a trader and thus the volume of BFS’ authorised trading, both by turning him into the most important trader on the exchange and by improving the apparent results he could achieve for BFS’ customers. Therefore the profits from such agency trading were related to D&T’s negligent failure to detect Leeson’s unauthorised trading and are to be taken into account in assessing D&T’s liability.
Profits apparently earned from Leeson’s trading

D&T contended that they should receive a credit for the monies paid or credited by BFS to BSJ, BSL and BSLL as apparent profits from its switching activities on their behalves. Up to the end of April 1994, those apparent profits were £12.46 million
Q8 pages 6 and 7 . Those companies did receive credit for the apparent profits, though they were far exceeded by the amounts paid to BFS as margin. Most of that was in fact used for margining the 88888 account and, when the collapse came, BFS was unable to repay it.
D&T relied on three grounds (a fourth, based on insolvency set-off, was not pursued once BSJ, the proponent of the insolvency set-off issue, ceased to participate in the proceedings):

the profits were received by BFS, and it is irrelevant that BFS then paid them to other companies. First, the profits were not genuinely owed to those companies because they were the product of unauthorised trading. Secondly, if BFS is able to ignore the fact that its customers in fact paid its losses (by the funding they provided), the court should also ignore the fact that BFS paid the profits to its customers: that was res inter alios acta;

even if the profits were to be treated as accruing to other companies than BFS, they should not be ignored. D&T relied on Linden Gardens Trust Ltd v Lenesta Sludge [1994] 1 AC 85 and McAlpine v Panatown [2001] 1 AC 518, as cases in which the claimant was able to recover in full, even though another company in the group suffered the loss. Similarly the fact that another company in the group received profits should not prevent them being taken into account in assessing the claimant’s right to recover; and
the profits could be taken into account by applying section 727. I deal with this at paragraphs 1146 to 1148 below.

In response, BFS contended that the profits generated by switching were not received by BFS for its own benefit and did not benefit BFS in any way. D&T could produce no direct authority in support of their argument and had to rely by analogy on the Linden Gardens and Panatown cases. Mr Brindle pointed out that BFS was already giving credit for the commission and interest earned on the switching business, so there was not an absolute black hole such as concerned the courts in those cases. That also meant that it would be double recovery for D&T to receive credit for the customer’s profits as well as BFS’ commission and interest. Finally, the House of Lords in Panatown did not approve Lord Griffiths’ wide formulation in Linden Gardens: in both cases the majority of the House applied the well-established Albazero principle. That did not apply here and it would be a huge leap in the law for the court to make up a principle to fill what it might perceive as a gap.

I reject D&T’s argument (i). The profits were apparently earned by BFS as agent for its customers and they belonged to those customers. It is true that BFS may have paid the profits under a mistake, but BFS is estopped from demanding them back.

Nor does the fact that its customers paid BFS’ losses justify the court in ignoring the fact that BFS paid the profits to its customers. BFS’ unauthorised trading resulted in losses which were incurred on BFS’ own account, whether or not BFS met those losses without authority out of loans from BSL and BSLL. By contrast, the profits were those of BFS’ customers.

D&T’s ground (ii) is stronger. Panatown was a case in which one group company, A, contracted with B for building works to be carried out on property owned by another group company, C. The works were defective. The issue was whether A could sue B and recover the cost of effecting remedial works, even though A had suffered no direct loss as a result of the breach.

All their Lordships held that in principle A could recover. Lord Clyde and Lord Jauncey did so on the basis of what was referred to as the “narrow ground” relied upon by the majority in Linden Gardens. As explained by Lord Clyde at page 535E, this was “to permit the contracting party to recover damages for the loss which he and a third party has suffered, being duly accountable to them in respect of their actual loss”. Lord Goff, Lord Millett and Lord Browne-Wilkinson preferred (or in Lord Browne-Wilkinson’s case assumed) the “broad ground” put forward by Lord Griffiths in Linden Gardens: A could sue for his own loss of bargain in not having the contract performed.
D&T relied in particular on the speech of Lord Clyde at page 535H, where he said:

“The problem that has arisen in the present case is one which is most likely to arise in the context of the domestic affairs of a family group or the commercial affairs of a group of companies. How the members of such a group choose to arrange their own affairs among themselves should not be a matter of necessary concern to a third party who has undertaken to one of their number to perform services in which they all have some interest. It should not be a ground of escaping liability that the party who instructed the work should not be the one who sustained the loss or all of the loss which in whole or in part has fallen on another member or members of the group. But the resolution of the problem in any particular case has to be reached in light of its own circumstances.”

That clearly has echoes in the present situation. In Linden Gardens and Panatown, the House of Lords felt that losses should not disappear into a legal black hole because of the accidents of corporate group structure. A should be able to recover for loss sustained by C. Likewise in this case it would seem wrong if profits, earned from the activity which it is alleged that D&T should have detected, should be ignored merely because they were booked to BSL and BSJ rather than to BFS. A (BFS) should have to give credit for profits received by C (BSL and BSJ).
Somewhat reluctantly, I do not feel justified in so deciding. This is for two reasons.

First, as BFS submitted, it seems to me to be too great a leap in the law for me to apply the Panatown principle in this situation. The intricate legal argument in Panatown was only necessary because the House of Lords adhered firmly to the principle that companies in the same group had separate corporate personalities. Their Lordships started from the general rule that company A could only sue B for loss suffered by A, not for loss suffered by its sister company C. Their dilemma was to find ways round that rule. The case provides no support for treating BFS, BSJ and BSL as one entity in calculating damages.

In this case, the basic position is clear: BFS suffered loss whereas other group companies received the profits. The principles of corporate personality which formed the basis of the judgments in Panatown indicate that BFS does not have to give credit for those profits. There is no direct authority justifying me in departing from that conclusion. Panatown and Linden Gardens dealt with a different situation, the converse of this one, and (as the next paragraphs will show) the reasoning in those cases is not easily applicable to this case.

Secondly, even if it is open to me to apply Panatown by analogy, D&T’s argument fails. Clearly there must be a connection between the profits paid out and the losses which are claimed before credit should be given. It is not enough for D&T to say that BSL’s profits and BFS’ losses arose out of the same unauthorised trading: if some of the profits of Leeson’s unauthorised trading had been paid out to BNP, it is not obvious that BFS should give credit for them, and in Panatown it was not enough for A to say that its claim and C’s loss all arose out of the same transaction. Rather, their Lordships took two different approaches:

the narrow ground, favoured by two of their Lordships, was that A could recover from B in respect of C’s loss, as long as (in Lord Clyde’s view, quoted above) A was legally obliged to account to C for the damages it recovered or (in Lord Jauncey’s view at page 574C) A “has made good, or intends to make good, the effects of the breach”. So A could recover damages only if it would use them to remedy C’s loss. In the present case, the issue is whether A must give credit for profits received by C. The analogous condition to that applied in Panatown is that A (that is, BFS) can only be required to give credit for those profits if it received or will receive the benefit of them;

the broad ground, favoured by three of their Lordships, focussed on A alone. It allowed A to sue for its own loss in not receiving the benefit for which it contracted (that is, performance of the contract), whoever in the group suffered the financial loss. The analogous argument in our situation would be that A (BFS) has to give credit for the profits if it received the benefit of them. It is also worth noting that Lords Goff and Millett required A’s intention to spend the damages in remedying the breach to be taken into account when assessing its right to substantial damages. As Lord Millett said, at page 593C:

“It is sufficient that the necessary remedial work will obviously have to be carried out, and that it will have to be carried out at the expense of the group. Whether it is carried out directly or indirectly by or at the expense of Panatown itself or of another member of the group is not material. What matters is that the work will be done and that doing it will enable Panatown to obtain whatever benefit it sought to obtain as a member of the Unex Group by entering into the building contract. It will not, to use the language of Oliver J, obtain an uncovenanted benefit.”
Again, therefore, the actual use of the damages to provide the benefit to C which was contracted for was necessary before A could recover substantial damages.

Therefore both approaches require me to look at whether BFS benefited from the profits received by BSL and BSJ. Normally a broker does not benefit from paying to its customers the profits made from its trading on their behalves, other than in reputational terms. I have considered whether the situation was different here, on the basis that BFS was effectively taking money from the 88888 account and giving it to its customers. To fund the margins on both its authorised and its unauthorised trading, BFS borrowed money from its customers, giving rise to a debt owed to them. The apparent profits taken from the 88888 account reduced BFS’ margin calls, and therefore its debt to its customers. It might be argued that to that extent they benefited BFS.

However that contention does not accord with the facts. Leeson created profits in the customers’ trading accounts by, for example, selling futures on their behalves to the 88888 account at above the market price. That created a profit in the trading account and a realised or unrealised loss in the 88888 account. That loss had to be met by funding from BFS’ customers (excess margins, double-counting the US dollar collateral and the Dollar Funding) or from BFS’ overdraft. Either increased BFS’ debt. Therefore an apparent profit credited to BSL may have reduced BFS’ next margin call on BSL’s trading account, but it increased BFS’ indebtedness to other sources of funding.

Accordingly BFS did not benefit from the profits paid to other Barings companies. Even if it is open to me to apply the rather strained analogy with Panatown which I have set out above, its application does not require BFS to give credit for those profits.
Accordingly D&T’s arguments (i) and (ii) in relation to the profits fail. I set out my conclusion on their argument (iii) at paragraphs 1146 to 1148 below.
BFS’ recovery under the Coopers settlement

I have mentioned at paragraphs 14 and 15 the settlement reached in late 2001 between Plc, BSL, BFS, ING and BSJ, on the one hand, and C&LL and C&LS (“the Coopers defendants”), on the other, which settled the claims brought against the Coopers defendants in this litigation. The claims brought against the Coopers defendants had been as follows
see Plc/BSL original opening, pages 11-15 and 278-313 :

BFS claimed against C&LS only, in respect of the 1994 audit of BFS. It claimed the amount of the losses suffered by BFS as a result of Leeson’s unauthorised trading between 3 February 1995 and the collapse on 23 February 1995;

Plc claimed against C&LL, in respect of the December 1992, 1993 and 1994 audits of the Plc group. It claimed against C&LS in respect of the 1994 audit of the consolidation schedules of BFS. Plc claimed the loss of the value of the Plc group from both firms and claimed in respect of overpaid bonuses in 1994 from C&LL only;
BSL claimed against C&LL only, in respect of all three years. It claimed the loss of the Dollar Funding, the loss of the value of the BSL group and overpaid bonuses in 1994.

Under the settlement, the Coopers defendants paid £65 million to Plc, BSL and BFS in settlement of the above claims. That amount was not appropriated between the individual claimants or between the various claims. D&T contended that, insofar as the settlement monies paid by the Coopers defendants were on account of losses which BFS was claiming from D&T, BFS was obliged to give credit for them.

Three issues were identified. Firstly, BFS contended that, in default of appropriation by the payer, it is open to the recipient of a settlement payment to appropriate it as the recipient sees fit between the various claims which are being settled. The liquidators of the Barings parties appropriated the Coopers defendants’ payment to the claims in respect of the post-31 December 1994 period. Therefore there was no overlap between recovery from the Coopers defendants and the claims now brought against D&T. D&T responded that it was not open to the recipient unilaterally to appropriate the settlement monies to particular claims. That was for the court to do.

Secondly, BFS contended that, if it were necessary to go behind its appropriation, BFS made no claims against the Coopers defendants in respect of the pre-31 December 1994 period, so again there could be no overlap. D&T responded that it was not enough to look at BFS’ claims against the Coopers defendants. Plc’s and BSL’s claims were reflective of BFS’ claims. Therefore, if any part of the settlement monies related to the pre-31 December 1994 period, D&T should be given credit for it. BFS replied that, in the light of Gould v Vaggelas [1983-1985. 157 CLR 215], such an overlap would not prevent recovery in full by BFS. Double-recovery was prevented by subrogation, or by BSL having to give credit, in its claim against C&LL, for the value of the debt owed to it by BFS.

Thirdly, BFS accepted that it could not appropriate the settlement monies to claims which were obviously unsustainable. However it contended that the court could not be required to try the settled claims in their entirety in order to decide whether they would have succeeded. It should adopt the approach of section 1(4) of the Civil Liability (Contribution) Act 1978 and ask only whether the Coopers defendants “would have been liable assuming that the factual basis of the claim against [them would have been] established.” In any event, BFS’ claims against C&LS were not just sustainable, but clearly well-founded, unlike the overlapping claims. D&T responded that the court should appropriate monies to a non-overlapping claim only if the recipient were able to establish that that claim would have succeeded at trial, to at least the amount of the settlement monies sought to be appropriated to it. Given the degree of management fault present in 1995, the claims against C&LS were actually very weak.
Can BFS appropriate the settlement monies to non-overlapping claims?

I shall begin with the first and third issues, which are inter-related. I should point out at the start that the parties argued the issue on the basis that the relevant date for deciding whether claims were overlapping was 31 December 1994, that being the date of BFS’ self-imposed cut-off on its claims against D&T. However I have concluded that D&T are not liable for losses incurred after the end of April 1994. Therefore the issue is whether any recovery from the Coopers defendants relates to claims in respect of the period before that date, not 31 December 1994.

Both parties referred me to the cases of Townsend v Stone Toms (1984) 27 BLR 26 and Banque Keyser Ullman v Skandia Insurance (No. 2) [1988] 2 All ER 880. In Townsend, one defendant (D1) made a payment into court which was accepted by the claimant. The other defendant (D2) argued that it was entitled to credit for all or some of the payment. The payment had not been appropriated between claims that were only against D1, those that were only against D2 and those that were against both. In the absence of any material indicating how the apportionment should be made, the court assessed the true value of the claims and compared them with the amount of the payment. It concluded that the payment exceeded the value of both the claims against D1 only and the overlapping claims. So the claimant’s entitlement to pursue D2 in relation to the overlapping claims was extinguished by the payment in. The Court of Appeal approved that approach. Purchas LJ said at page 53:

“Where the previous recovery stems from the acceptance of a payment into court made and accepted, not only in respect of the claim for damages under consideration, but also in respect of other claims not relevant, the court must decide, and it is for the plaintiff to establish, by how much that part of the payment attributable to the instant claim falls short of the total value of the claim itself. For my part I cannot see how this exercise can be done without an investigation of the other claims… For these reasons the learned judge was perfectly correct to investigate the value of the claims between the appellants and [D1], as well as the claims between the appellants and [D2].”

In Banque Keyser Ullman, the claimant had settled with D1. The claimant sought to appropriate the settlement monies to its claims against D1 only (including its claims for costs), and not to give any credit for those monies against its overlapping claims against D1 and D2. Steyn J said at page 882:

“I am satisfied that [D1] would have been held liable in full for the agreed costs if the matter had proceeded to trial against [D1]. The principle appears to be that if a plaintiff who receives payment from one tortfeasor establishes an additional separate claim against that tortfeasor, the payment is allocated first to that claim, and credit must be given in favour of the second tortfeasor only for the excess necessarily referable to the overlapping claim. That seems to me the approach indicated by the Court of Appeal judgments in Townsend v Stone Toms… and by the actual decision in The Morgengry… It also appears to me to be the approach which is required by an application of first principles.”
In relation to the claim for costs which had been disallowed against D2, Steyn J continued at page 884:

“In Townsend, the Court of Appeal held that, once there is a prima facie case that the plaintiff has received money from a second tortfeasor which reduces his loss, it is for him to show that the payment relates to some separate claim against the second tortfeasor. That involves showing that the separate claim was sustainable on the facts and in law. In my judgement [the plaintiffs’] argument that they would have recovered against [D1] the costs which were disallowed against [D2] ought not to succeed. I do not regard it as a reasonably foreseeable head of loss, and its recovery in an action against [D1] is not demanded by the dictates of common sense or justice. It is too remote. In any event, [the plaintiff has] failed to discharge the burden of proving that this alleged separate claim would have been likely to succeed at a trial against [D1].”

These passages from Banque Keyser Ullman demonstrate that the Barings parties may appropriate the settlement monies received from the Coopers defendants to the post-31 December 1994 claims, as long as those claims meet the necessary threshold. The real issue is the level of that threshold: must the court decide whether the claims would have succeeded at trial, or is some lesser scrutiny required?

Mr Brindle for BFS pointed out that, in Banque Keyser Ullman, Steyn J gave the judgment from which I have quoted above at the end of a full trial. He already had a clear and informed view on the strength of the costs claims which were in issue. He was therefore able to decide without any need for further evidence that the claim for disallowed costs referred to in the second passage would have failed at trial. Mr Brindle distinguished Townsend on the grounds that there was there only one claimant; the court there had been given no material at all on which to base an appropriation; and that the payment there was a payment into court, which is made under a special procedure and which it may be more difficult for a claimant unilaterally to appropriate to particular claims. By contrast, the general rule, where a creditor is owed two debts by a debtor and receives a payment which is not appropriated between them, is that the creditor may appropriate the payment between the debts as he thinks fit.

Mr Brindle suggested that Steyn J would be horrified if he were told that his ruling required me to hear the full case against the Coopers defendants, over the course of several weeks, purely in order to decide this point. I agree with him, and would be very reluctant to make such a finding unless authority compelled me to do so. I do not think either Banque Keyser Ullman or Townsend do so compel me.

Banque Keyser Ullman is explicable on the grounds suggested by Mr Brindle. In Townsend the Court of Appeal stated that even a payment into court may be appropriated to particular claims, by the claimant requesting an apportionment in the notice of payment in. That would be conclusive, as long as the apportionment were not collusive or not made bona fide (per Oliver LJ at page 41). In the case of a negotiated settlement, it seems to me that the normal rule allowing appropriation by the recipient should apply (Halsbury’s Laws, 4th ed., volume 9(1) paragraph 956), subject to the sort of low-level threshold indicated by Oliver LJ. One of Mr Brindle’s formulations of that threshold was whether the claims were obviously unsustainable. That seems to me a preferable approach to his alternative approach, by analogy to the Civil Liability (Contribution) Act 1978, which would pay no regard at all to the chances of the claimant making out his claim at trial.

In any event, while I should stress that I have not heard evidence sufficient to decide the claims relating to the 1994 audits and the events of January and February 1995, some aspects of those claims have been opened to me and I have been taken to documentation, and transcripts of the evidence of witnesses to the BOBS and SIR inspectors, relating to them. There were clearly serious questions to be asked as to C&LS’ failure to investigate the “funds to be reverse” item in the course of their early work in November 1994 and as to both Coopers firms’ treatment of the SLK receivable (see paragraphs 460 to 462), however much management was also at fault. Indeed, in relation to the “funds to be reverse” issue, the main dispute seemed likely to be whether C&LS were negligent in November 1994, or only in January or February 1995, an issue which is irrelevant in view of my April 1994 cut-off mentioned above.

By contrast, there were of course no claims against C&LS relating to the 1992 and 1993 audits. The alleged overlapping claims against C&LL seem to me weak. The main such claim persisted in by D&T for the purpose of its Part 20 proceedings was the failure to advise BSL of the defects in its settlements systems, and it follows from my conclusions at paragraphs 1012 to 1020 that there was little substance to that.

Accordingly I am far from finding the claims against the Coopers defendants relating to post-31 December 1994 events to be obviously unsustainable. Indeed I find it very likely that, if the Coopers defendants had been found liable at trial, that liability would have been in relation to post-31 December 1994 events and not in relation to events earlier than that, let alone events earlier than 30 April 1994. The amount claimed from C&LS alone in relation to losses in February 1995 was £417 million plus interest
day 155 page 184 (even ignoring Plc’s and BSL’s loss of group claims against both Coopers defendants in relation to that period). In my judgement, attribution of the whole of the £65 million under the settlement to post-31 December 1994 is bona fide and not to be re-opened by the court.
Relevance of recoveries by Plc and BSL

In the light of that conclusion, I do not need to decide issue (ii): is it conclusive that BFS had no claims against the Coopers defendants relating to the period pre-31 December 1994, or do I have to take account of recoveries by Plc and BSL relating to that period? Part of BSL’s claim against C&LL was for losses which were conceded in the strike-out application to be reflective of those claimed by BFS against D&T. That reflective element was, given the limit BFS has placed on its claims against D&T, the Dollar Funding up to 31 December 1994. However Plc and BSL had other claims, for the Dollar Funding after that date, the loss of their respective groups and overpaid bonuses. BFS had claims against C&LS in relation to its losses after 31 December 1994. I have concluded that it was open to the Barings parties to allocate their recovery under the Coopers settlement to the non-overlapping claims. Therefore, whether or not BFS would have had to give credit for an earlier recovery by BSL in respect of reflective loss, in fact the recovery could be, and was, allocated to non-reflective loss.
Conclusion
For the reasons given above, I conclude in relation to the three issues of principle in relation to damages that:

BFS is obliged to give credit for one half of its profits from commission and interest on its non-switching activities from 1 November 1992 to 1 March 1994 and for all of such profits from 1 March 1994 to the cut-off date of 30 April 1994 (or any later cut-off date that is applied);

BFS is not obliged to give credit for the apparent profits from Leeson’s switching business received by BSL, BSLL and BSJ under the two legal grounds considered above. I address below D&T’s third ground, the operation of section 727 Companies Act 1985 or its Singapore equivalent; and

BFS, Plc and BSL were entitled to appropriate their recovery under the Coopers settlement to their claims which did not overlap with BFS’ claim against D&T. Therefore BFS is not obliged to give credit in its claim for any element of that recovery.
SECTION 727 COMPANIES ACT 1985
Section 391(1) of the Singapore Companies Act provides:

“If in any proceedings for negligence, default, breach of duty or breach of trust against a person to whom this section applies [which includes an auditor], it appears to the Court before which the proceedings are taken that he is or may be liable in respect thereof but that he has acted honestly and reasonably and that, having regard to all the circumstances of the case including those connected with his appointment, he ought fairly to be excused for the negligence, default or breach, the Court may relieve him either wholly or partly from his liability on such terms as the Court thinks fit”
E4/39A

It is common ground between the parties that, although the Singaporean provision applies in this case, its effect can be assumed to be identical to that of section 727 Companies Act 1985. It is to that section that I shall refer in the remainder of this judgment. A relieving provision in similar terms applicable to trustees is to be found in section 61 of the Trustee Act 1925.

D&T did not contend that I should use section 727 to relieve them wholly from liability, if they were otherwise found to be liable. Their position was that I could use the section to relieve them partly from liability, in relation to three specific areas:

profits from the switching business. D&T contended that the Court should relieve them of liability to the extent that other Barings companies received apparent profits from Leeson’s activities, an issue already discussed in the preceding section on Damages; and

cut-off of damages. The level of losses on the 88888 account fluctuated during 1994, depending on whether Leeson traded on that account profitably or at a loss. I have already discussed this question at paragraphs 880 to 891 of this judgment. As a final line of defence, D&T contended that the section could be used to relieve them from liability so as to take account of periods of profitable trading by Leeson on the 88888 account occurring after any cut-off date.
The interpretation of section 727

As has been frequently remarked, there is an obvious paradox in the wording of section 727. It allows a defendant who has been found liable for negligence to be excused wholly or partially on the grounds that he acted “honestly and reasonably” and, in the light of all the circumstances of the case, “ought fairly to be excused”. A number of judges have had to consider how a negligent defendant can be found to have acted reasonably. As Hoffmann LJ remarked in Re D’Jan of London [1993] BCC 646, at page 649:

“It may seem odd that a person found to have been guilty of negligence, which involves failing to take reasonable care, can ever satisfy a court that he acted reasonably. Nevertheless, the section clearly contemplates that he may do so and it follows that conduct may be reasonable for the purposes of section 727 despite amounting to lack of reasonable care at common law.”

In that case Hoffmann LJ applied the section so as partially to excuse a director for his negligent breach of duty to the company. This was on the grounds that his breach was not gross and, since the company at the time was prosperous and the director and his wife were the sole shareholders, his breach did not seem to be putting anyone’s interests at risk other than his own and his wife’s.

The paradox was explored in more detail in the Australian case of Maelor Jones v Heywood-Smith (1989) 54 SASR 285. At the time of the facts giving rise to that case, section 365 of the Australian Companies Act was in similar terms to section 727, although, since then, the reference to “reasonably” has been removed. Olssen J, having quoted Moffitt J in Pacific Acceptance v Forsyth, as follows:

“[The defendants] submit that, if an auditor formed an honest judgement on a matter after due consideration of the question, or perhaps in accordance with prevailing practice, but the court nevertheless considered the judgement erroneous and negligent, the court could nevertheless find that the auditor had acted reasonably. They submitted the court might do likewise if the act of negligence found was casual or minor. It was conceded that the breach of duty would have to have some such quality as in these examples to make it reasonable. As on the defendants’ own interpretation of the section I think the defendants fail on the facts, it is not in point to determine the questions raised by the plaintiff, upon which I express no opinion…

“I should add also that the provision in section 365 is that the person seeking the benefit of the section must have acted reasonably, there being no limitation as to the field in which he must act reasonably. It is not, for example, limited to acting reasonably in the actual discharge of his duty of care. There seems no reason why, when he comes to be excused, his conduct generally so far as it is relevant should not be looked at to see whether he acted reasonably…”,
continued (at page 294):

“In my opinion, it is in the foregoing dicta that the resolution of the dilemma earlier adverted to is to be found. Whilst it may well be that, in a particular situation, the very circumstances which give rise to a finding of negligence may be so pervasive and compelling as also to demand a conclusion that a person had acted unreasonably for the purposes of the exculpatory section, nevertheless that section is to be taken to directing its attention to a much wider area of concern – both in point of scope and time frame. The examples relied upon by the defence as cited by Moffitt J seem to me apt illustrations of the issues involved.
“I am therefore content to construe s. 365(1) in that manner.”

Having cited Re Allsop, Whittaker v Bamford [1914] 1 Ch 1 and stressing both the “unfettered judicial discretion” involved in applying the section and the caution to be exercised in doing so, Olssen J concluded:

“the court… ought not to shrink from giving effect to its sense of fairness and justice. It should not hesitate, in a proper case, to relieve a person from what, having regard to particular facts and circumstances – particularly where the person concerned has acted honourably, fairly, in good faith and in a commonsense manner as judged by the standards of others of a similar professional background – from what might otherwise be seen to be a harsh and oppressive consequence of the strict application of the law, if applied in the absence of the considerations identified by the section.”

In National Trustee Company of Australasia v General Finance Company of Australasia [1905] AC 373, at page 381, dealing with the equivalent provision applicable to trustees in the Victorian Trusts Act, the Privy Council stated:

“The Courts in the Colony have found that the appellants acted honestly and reasonably… Mr Terrell contended that, these two things being established, the right to relief followed as a matter of course; but that is clearly not the construction of the Act. Unless both are proved, the Court cannot help the trustees; but, if both are made out, there is then a case for the Court to consider whether the trustee ought fairly to be excused for the breach, looking at all the circumstances.”

I conclude from the above authorities that section 727 is available to me if D&T acted honestly and reasonably. They may have acted reasonably for the purposes of the section even though I have found them to have acted negligently, if they acted in good faith and their negligence was technical or minor in character, and not “pervasive and compelling”. Nor am I limited to consideration of the nature of D&T’s fault, but may take into account wider considerations, such as in D’Jan the economic reality that the defendant and his wife owned the entire company. Similar considerations weighed with the court in Re Duomatic [1969] 2 Ch 365.

If these threshold tests are met, I have a wide discretion as to whether D&T ought fairly to be excused. In exercising that discretion, I am required to look at all the circumstances. However I clearly should not apply the section so as to negate the basic principles of liability in this sort of case. Having found that D&T were negligent, I should not use the section to relieve them from liability merely because the negligence was not particularly gross (to use Hoffmann LJ’s term). Likewise fault by BFS, and the comparison between its fault and D&T’s, is taken account of adequately in admitting a defence of contributory negligence.

Something more is required to justify relief. In D’Jan it was the nature of the company and the defendant’s shareholding. In a recent Australian case, Circle Petroleum v Greenslade [1998] QSC 172, which I discuss below, the Court was willing to take into account the apparent fairness to the defendant of the relief being sought against him which was otherwise enforceable.
Does section 727 apply to D&T?

BFS did not suggest that D&T acted other than honestly. However it contended that the negligence alleged against D&T was not trivial. If D&T were found to have been negligent as alleged, they did not act reasonably and therefore the section could not apply. The only case in which the section had been applied to a defendant found liable in negligence was D’Jan. The circumstances which rendered the defendant’s conduct reasonable there were far removed from the present case: in particular, there is no question in this case of only the defendant’s money being at risk.

In my view D&T did act reasonably for the purposes of section 727, interpreted in the light of the authorities I have cited above. Perusal of their working files shows that their audits were conducted (as summarised in Schedule F to this judgment) with great thoroughness, for very low fees. Of the many allegations of negligence originally made by BFS, only two were proved. Of those, D&T’s negligence in relation to the ¥670m was of a somewhat technical nature. Miss Koo was given, by duly-authorised BFS staff, a fraudulent explanation for a reconciling item. I have held that she should have checked the explanation more thoroughly than she did, but she did carry out some checks and, in the view of Mr Spence, the least partial of the audit experts, those checks were sufficient. I found the issue of negligence to be a finely-balanced question of judgement.

The imbalance of margins in 1993 was a clearer case of negligence. Even there, the imbalance was evident towards the end of an audit which had otherwise appeared wholly without incident. D&T should have investigated it only because of the specialist knowledge which they had. BFS and BSL should have also had such knowledge and should have investigated, but they did not. Given the cut-off I have applied, this head of negligence caused none of the loss for which D&T are liable.
Therefore the negligence found was limited in extent and technical in nature and certainly was not “pervasive and compelling”. In these circumstances, I hold that section 727 is capable of applying.
Ought D&T fairly to be excused?
D&T invoked the section in relation to two issues, both of which related to the quantification of damage.
Profits received by other Barings companies

I have described this issue at paragraphs 1090 to 1106 above. I there rejected two of D&T’s arguments in favour of giving credit for the profits received by other Barings companies from Leeson’s trading. These were that (i) the profits were received by BFS, and any later payment to other companies was irrelevant; and (ii) an argument based on McAlpine v Panatown that the profits should be taken into account even though other companies received them.

D&T’s third argument was to invoke section 727. They pointed out that Barings was run as a single group, with profits booked to whichever company it was most advantageous to book them to, for the purpose of putting the Barings group in the best fiscal position achievable and minimising the obligation to pay margin to exchanges. The profits were booked to companies which are the sole creditors in BFS’ liquidation. Therefore, to the extent that their proofs of debt are met, they will receive payment in respect of the profits twice over if BFS enforces its claim in full. The profits were in most cases artificial and were the other side of the coin to the losses, made in the course of the same trading and at the expense of the 88888 account: Leeson generated profits for BSL and BSJ by effectively transferring money into their trading accounts from the 88888 account. If D&T had detected Leeson’s unauthorised trading, the profits would have been stopped as well as the losses. It would be quite unfair to make D&T liable for the losses but to give them no credit for the profits.

These points seem to me valid ones. In Circle Petroleum v Greenslade, the Supreme Court of Queensland, in applying the equivalent section to section 727, considered that it was legitimate to have regard to the consequences of a damages award. Muir J said:

“I now turn to the defendant’s submission that relief should be given on the basis that the defendant, being an equal owner of the plaintiff, has directly suffered half the loss arising as a result of trading with Promco. If it was correct that, by being an equal shareholder with Ampol, Greenslade suffered half the loss caused by Promco’s default, it would be reasonable, in my view, to afford the defendant some relief. Not to do so would result in a windfall to the other shareholder of the plaintiff. It would also cause the defendant's loss as a shareholder to be magnified. However, the facts are such that the extent, if at all, to which the defendant will be treated unjustly if some relief is not given having regard to the corporate structure is by no means clear... ”

In this case the same companies will benefit from the recovery of the losses caused by Leeson’s trading as benefited from the profits caused by that same trading. Both losses and profits resulted from D&T’s negligence, which allowed Leeson’s trading to continue. To take account of the losses and to ignore the profits would be to give a windfall to those companies, and be unjust to D&T.

I conclude therefore that D&T should be relieved from liability to BFS for the profits received by other Barings companies arising from Leeson’s switching business up to the cut-off date at the end of April 1994. In the event that my conclusions on that or alternative cut-off dates do not stand, this relief should apply to subsequent profits as appropriate up to 31 December 1994.
The reduction in BFS’ losses after the cut-off date

I have described this issue at paragraphs 880 to 891 above. I have concluded there that it is open to D&T to elect the date by reference to which damages are to be assessed, as long as it is after the date on which I have found their negligence ceased to be an operative cause of BFS’ loss. They are thereby able to take advantage of any reduction in BFS’ losses which occurred after the first possible cut-off date.

Should I be wrong in that conclusion, D&T submitted that I may reach the same result by the application of section 727. I agree. For the reasons given in the paragraphs I have mentioned, it seems to me unjust that D&T should not benefit from Leeson’s profitable trading after the cut-off date, merely because later still Leeson incurred further losses. If BFS had not incurred those losses, it would have been able to claim only for the loss after giving credit for the profitable trading. Why should that position be affected by the fact that later still BFS suffered further losses, which were caused solely by BFS, not by D&T, and for which D&T are not liable? In my view it should not, and D&T ought fairly to be relieved of liability to that extent.

On the basis of a cut-off date of 30 April 1994, I would therefore if necessary apply section 727 to relieve D&T of liability for the difference between the losses on that date and those on 2 May (the subsequent date on which the losses were lowest), giving the same outcome as is set out at paragraph 891.
